resources.boxed: This task assumes you've completed the previous one, generic data structures.
resources.text: Refactoring means making significant changes in an already written codebase. Before you begin this task, refactor the improved data structures to have a common base class, MyCollection. This class should be generic.
resources.boxed:
The base class should provide methods to to iterate over the elements of the collections. This can be done by maintaining a reference to the current element, or storing the current index.

Also make the base class have abstract add and remove methods so every collection has these operations.
resources.text: The JDK has interfaces for such behaviour called java.util.Iterator and java.lang.Iterable. They have other, difficult to implement methods. For our purposes, a simple iterator is enough.
resources.boxed: When the next method is called but there are no more elements, a NoSuchElementException should be thrown. Also have a hasNext method which can tell if there are more elements or not, and a method which can reset the iterator to the beginning.
resources.text: The reason we need this common base class and the iterator functionality is so that a utility class can be created.
Create an abstract class which has generic methods. The following methods are needed:
resources.list:
• Printing a data structure (for any type).
  • Summing a data structure (only for elements that are Number subclasses).
  • Minimum and maximum finder methods (only for Comparable elements).

solution.code:
public abstract class MyCollection<T> {

    //used by the iteration
    protected int currentIndex;
    
    //the iterator method
    public abstract T next() throws NoSuchElementException;
    
    //helper method which can detect if we're at the end
    public boolean hasNext() {
         if(currentIndex == size()) {
              return false;
         }
         return true;
    }
    
    public void resetIterator() {
         currentIndex = 0;
    }
    
    public abstract void add(T element);
    
    public abstract T remove(T element);
    
    public abstract int size();
}

public class MyArrayList<T> extends MyCollection<T> {
    
    /*
    Other methods and members are the same as in the previous task.
    */
    
    @Override
    public T next() throws NoSuchElementException {
         //check if we can get next
         if(!hasNext()) throw new NoSuchElementException();
         //next element exists
         return get(currentIndex++);
    }
}

public class MyStack<T> extends MyCollection<T> {
    
    /*
    Other methods and members are unchanged.
    */

    @Override
    public T next() throws NoSuchElementException {
         //check if we can get next
         if(!hasNext()) throw new NoSuchElementException();
         //next element exists
         return list.get(currentIndex++);
    }

    @Override
    public void add(T element) {
         push(element);
    }

    @Override
    public T remove(T element) throws UnsupportedOperationException {
         //we don't allow removing by element with a stack
         throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
    }
}
solution.text: Now that we have the improved data structures, we can write the utility class:
solution.code:
public abstract class MyUtils {

    //print method, accepts any collection
    public static void printCollection(MyCollection<?> collection) {
         collection.resetIterator(); //must be done!
         while(collection.hasNext()) {
              System.out.println(collection.next().toString());
         }
    }
    
    //Sum method, accepts only numeric collection
    public static double sumCollection(MyCollection<? extends Number> collection) {
         collection.resetIterator(); //must be done!
         double sum = 0;
         while(collection.hasNext()) {
              sum += collection.next().doubleValue();
         }
         return sum;
    }
    
    //Max method, only accepts comparable collections
    public static <T extends Comparable<T>> T maximum(MyCollection<T> collection) {
         collection.resetIterator(); //must be done!
         T max = collection.next();
         while(collection.hasNext()) {
              T element = collection.next();
              int compare = element.compareTo(max);
              if(compare >= 1) { //we found a new max
                   max = element;
              }
         }
         return max;
    }
    
    //Min method, only accepts comparable collections
    public static <T extends Comparable<T>> T minimum(MyCollection<T> collection) {
         collection.resetIterator(); //must be done!
         T min = collection.next();
         while(collection.hasNext()) {
              T element = collection.next();
              int compare = element.compareTo(min);
              if(compare <= -1) { //we found a new min
                   min = element;
              }
         }
         return min;
    }
}
